name: Streams 3.2 Developers Virtual Conference
description:
THIS IS A WEB CONFERENCE ONLY - TIME INDICATED IS LOCAL START TIME. SEE BELOW FOR DETAILS.

IBM InfoSphere Streams V3.2 (referred to as Streams) delivers a highly scalable, agile software infrastructure to perform in-motion analytics on a wide variety of relational and non-relational data types that enter the enterprise at unprecedented volumes and speed, and from thousands of real-time sources. Streams V3.2 includes new features and functions designed to instantly analyze and fuse massive volumes of data and integrates with existing infrastructures. It delivers new capabilities to improve usability, support enterprise readiness, and streamline enterprise integration.

WHAT:

The following new features and functions, which will be covered during the Streams Developer Conference:

Usability:
• Remote Development with Streams Studio for Windows and Linux
• User Defined Parallelism
• Java Streams development simplification

Enterprise readiness:
• Operational Decision Management adapter for business rules
• Access to application data using Representational State Transfer (REST)

Enterprise integration:
• MQTT adapters
• Hadoop Big SQL support
• HP Vertica Analytic Database support

Who should attend:

The event assumes you are familiar with Streams. If you are not, please either try the Big Data University Streams course or review some of the Streams videos on YouTube.

WHEN:

Webcast on Thursday November 14, 2013 from 10:00AM to 6:00PM U.S. Eastern Standard Time.

WHERE:

The webcast will be recorded and posted to Big Data University (BDU) at the following Big Data University course ID.

NOTE: There will be no physical location for this meetup and it will all be online.

To get more info, download presentations, get detailed agenda and to register for the event check out the BDU Streams Developers Virtual Conference landing page.

The detailed agenda will be posted at the BDU class/event page after Oct 31.

Please join us on the live LotusLive meeting webcast. The conference ID is 2058889. Audio in listen only mode will be available on the webcast.

To ask questions during Q&A periods, please use the following conference information:

USA Toll-Free: 1-888-426-6840

USA Caller Paid: 1-215-861-6239

For Other Countries call in numbers use this link.

Participant Code: 7821035

We look forward to sharing details about these new capabilities.

name: Big Data Developer Day
description:
REGISTRATION WILL CLOSE END OF DAY TOMORROW (TUESDAY).  IF YOU HAVE NOT ALREADY REGISTERED, PLEASE DO SO RIGHT AWAY.  PLEASE USE THE LINK BELOW TO REGISTER FOR BIG DATA DEVELOPER DAY IN TORONTO ON MARCH 27TH.  SEATING CAPACITY IS LIMITED. 


http://ibm.co/1nLalZA


Join us and participate in an exclusive Big Data Developer Day hosted by the IBM Big Data team.   Open source Apache Hadoop is a great framework for distributed processing of large data sets. But there’s a difference between "playing" with big data versus solving real problems. The reality is that Hadoop alone might not be enough. Experience IBM’s enterprise-class Hadoop product, InfoSphere BigInsights, which enhances open source Hadoop with required enterprise capabilities including: analytics, visualization, security, standard SQL, enterprise HBase, developer/admin tools, learn about the role of Big Data in Motion, Big Data Exploration and more. The morning session will include interactive Big Data use case discussions, an overview of what is big data, live demonstrations of key Big Data components (Big Data at Rest, Big Data in Motion).

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B27SpLOOhWw&list=PL7FnN5oi7Ez_p0XyFGI_XDF6C8Hj4R6-k&index=18

and, in the afternoon, get hands-on with Big Data using InfoSphere BigInsights Quick Start Edition and InfoSphere Streams Quick Start Edition with guidance from development experts. This is a unique opportunity to develop skills and learn about exciting technologies and techniques that you can immediately take back to your organization.

This event is FREE. Breakfast, Lunch and snacks will be provided.

Agenda (subject to change)


9:00 am to 9:30 am Breakfast & Registration

9:30 am to 10:30 am Welcome and Keynote - Big Data Overview

10:30 am to 11:15 am Big Data @ Rest (Hadoop) & Demo

11:15 am to 11:30 am Break

11:30 am to 12:15 pm Big Data in Motion & Demo (Streams)

12:15 pm to 1:00 pm Lunch

1:00 pm to 5:00 pm Hands-on Lab -


- Track 1     Hadoop
** maximize throughput leveraging Adaptive MapReduce
** leveraging full power of SQL with Hadoop

- Track 2     Streams
** the Programming Model for real time analytics
** integration with Analytics technologies...SPSS, R, etc.


5:15 PM Close Thank You for Attending


Labs will use BigInsights Quickstart VM and Streams Quickstart VM.  Here is a video on how to setup the BigInsights Quickstart VM. To learn more before hand and get hands on go to Big Data University. 

Seating is limited, please adjust your RSVP accordingly.

To guarantee your seat, you must register here: 

     http://ibm.co/1nLalZA


Registration is required.  This event is limited to only 50 seats. You may let others know that you are going to this event by clicking on the YES RSVP button on this Meetup page—however— your seat can not be guaranteed until you officially register at the link above.

Thanks and we look forward to seeing you soon!

name: SQL for Hadoop
description:
Join us for our next Big Data Developer Meetup to be held at the IBM Lab in Markham on Wednesday, May 7th.  RSVP on this meetup.

Hear from the development team about the latest SQL for Hadoop features in Big SQL.   Big SQL delivers some exciting capabilities including comprehensive SQL functionality that leverages advanced SQL compiler/runtime all with low latency and high performance. If you attended the Big Data Developer Day in Markham on March 27th, you would have heard a very brief introduction to the power of Big SQL an how it can enhance your Big Data projects.


Learn more about Big SQL here.

We will also offer a parallel track on Streams where you will be able to continue to enhance your practical knowledge of how you can leverage real time analytics.   The agenda for this track will be to give an overview of the new capabilities in InfoSphere Streams 3.2.1, Introduce Streams open development on github and Q&A.

Want to learn how to get stared with Real Time analytics?  Check out the Getting Started with Streams links.

Agenda 

6:00pm - 7:00pm          Registration, Dinner, Welcome &
                                           Networking
7:00pm - 9:00pm          SQL for Hadoop
                                           - Presentation, demos
                                           or
                                           Streams Track
                                           - Presentation, demo, hands on lab
                                           - InfoSphere Streams 3.2.1 update
                                              -- overview of new features
                                           - InfoSphere Streams open development
                                              -- discuss open toolkit development
                                              -- what is currently under development
                                              -- how to get involved
                                              -- brainstorm on new toolkits, new operators
                                           - Question and Answer

name: An Intro to Text Analytics on Big Data with a use case

venue.name: University of Toronto - OISE Building - Room 4422
venue.address_1: 252 Bloor Street West (St. George Subway Station)

description:
This will be the agenda for this event: 6:00 - 6:05pm - Registration and Welcome!

6:05 - 6:15pm - Recap from prior meetup events

6:15 - 7:00pm - Introducing Text Analytics with a use case and demo

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pMNkP0zxbo4

7:45 - 8:00pm - Networking Free refreshments/snacks will be available.

name: Hands-on: Develop with wearable technology and analyze big data
description:
One of the sources of Big Data are IoT and Wearable technology applications. For example, the Kiwi device collects 50 measurements per second.  Participate in this meetup to learn how you can collect data from wearables and analyze them.

This meetup has been created to support SportsHack 2014 (sportshackweekend.org) the very first wearable tech hack specific to Sports in Toronto. It's a great chance to network and potentially form teams for the hack which will happen on Nov 14 - 16, 2014.  If you will not be participating in the Hack, you are still invited!

Remember to register and use the 30 day Bluemix free trial. 

Agenda:

5:00pm - Network / Optionally form teams for SportsHack, hands-on with wearables

6:30pm - Technical presentation about wearables to be used on the SportsHack

7:00pm - Network / Optionally form teams for SportsHack, hands-on with wearables

10:00pm - End of event

Bring your laptops if you want to play with the wearables, and bring any wearable you may want to use in the SportsHack.  There will be Internet connectivity.

Four stations will be set up in this meetup:

Station #1: Muse (InteraXon)

Station #2: Myo (Thalmic Labs)

Station #3: Kiwi Device (Kiwi Wearables)

Station #4: Other wearables and devices that can complement a solution with wearables (Oculus Rift, bring your own!, Freescale devices)

Each station will have a number of wearable devices to try, and where you'll have a chance to write code using the wearable 's SDK (first come, first served). There will be mentors at each station that can help you speed up your learning process, and they can also demo apps they've written.  Feel free to arrive at any time between 5pm and 10pm. You can rotate between stations. In order to give a chance to everyone to play with the devices, the organizers may limit the time participants have per station.

Join us and have fun! 

Refreshments / snacks will be provided

Brought to you by:

Thanks to the DMZ (Ryerson University) for providing the venue and helping with logistics for this event

name: Big Data for Social Good Challenge

venue.name: Big Data for Social Good Challenge

description:
CALLING ALL DEVELOPERS .... JOIN THE BIG DATA FOR SOCIAL GOOD CHALLENGE

 

Big data exists in just about everything we use and do. It comes from phones, cars, roads, power lines, waterways, food crates, and innumerable other items you’d never think of as computers. This data speaks volumes about our collective behavior and society – so let’s use it to do something incredible! IBM invites developers and data enthusiasts to take a deep dive into real world civic issues using big data and the IBM Bluemix Analytics for Hadoop service. Analyze one of our curated datasets or bring your own (provided it meets these requirements)! Use Hadoop and your data to create a clickable and interactive data visualization to highlight insights that you’ve found.

 

Ready to get started? $40,000 in prizes will be awarded....

 

Register here:http://ibmhadoop.challengepost.com/

 

What to Create: Participants must create a working, clickable, and interactive data visualization utilizing the Analytics for Hadoop service on IBM Bluemix.

 

Data Requirements: Your data visualization must analyze one or more datasets included in the curated list of datasets on the Data page OR meet the data size, content, and licensing requirements described on the Data page. The total size of the Datasets analyzed must be between 500MB - 7GB in size.

 

Check out the requirements then go get your IBM Bluemix extended promo code and check out the datasets!

name: Hands-on: Bluemix Workshop - Wearables and Big Data on Bluemix

venue.name: UofT: Gerstein Science Information Centre (2nd Floor) - Sigmund Samuel Library Building

description:
This is the second meetup created in support of SportsHack 2014 (sportshackweekend.org), the very first wearable tech hack specific to Sports in Toronto. In this meetup we will cover Bluemix in more detail, and show you how to get different wearable devices connected to several Bluemix services, including dashDB (Analytics warehouse), and Analytics for Hadoop. Bluemix is the required platform to use for SportsHack. For info on the first meetup in support of SportsHack 2014, check this link.

Remember to register and use the 30 day Bluemix free trial prior to attending this meetup.  Bring your computer to work on the labs! - Internet access will be available. 

Agenda

6:25pm - 6:35pm IoT & NodeRed QuickLab

8:15pm - 8:25pm Myo to Bluemix demo 

8:25pm - 8:35pm Raspberry Pi to Bluemix demo 

8:35pm - 8:45pm Kiwi to Bluemix demo 

8:45pm - 8:55pm Kiwi to Bluemix QuickLab

Snacks/refreshments will be provided

Remember to register for your 30 day Bluemix free trial.  (30 days begins the day you register.)

name: Cutting Edge Real Time Analytics!
description:
The InfoSphere Streams development team continues to push the envelope of what's possible in the realm of Real Time Analytics! A number of interesting new features have been added to Streams and can all be previewed in the Streams 3.2.2 Beta VM image which is now available for download.


The main themes in 3.2.2 are:
1. IBM InfoSphere Streams for Microsoft Excel
2. Automated High Availability and Next Generation Architecture
3. Application Resiliency

See demonstrations of the new features and join in the discussion of the use cases and provide feedback to the development team who will be present at this session. The new features will be demonstrated, use cases discussed and provide feedback to the development team on the new features.

Come to the Meetup with the Beta installed and you will be able to follow along with many of the demos the presenter's will be stepping through.

https://developer.ibm.com/streamsdev/2014/10/24/streams-3-2-2-open-beta-now-available/

Agenda:

1:00 Introductions
1:15: Streams 3.2.2 Beta Image basics
1:30 Streams for Microsoft Excel
2:00 Domains High Availability and Console
2:45 break
3:00 Application Resiliency
3:45 Discussion:  Use cases, feedback. Q&A with Toronto Streams development team members.
4:30 Wrap-up

Visit the StreamsDev web site to keep up to date with the latest and greatest on IBM's InfoSphere Streams: https://developer.ibm.com/streamsdev/

Refreshments will be served.

name: An intro to IBM dashDB and design thinking

venue.name: UofT: Gerstein Science Information Centre (2nd Floor) - Sigmund Samuel Library Building

description:
ABSTRACT


IBM dashDB is a new data warehousing solution on the cloud which allows the user to visualize their data and perform data analysis through built-in analytics, R predictive modeling and other BI and ETL tools.

Design thinking is defined as combining empathy for the context of a problem, creativity in the generation of insights and solutions, and rationality in analyzing and fitting various solutions to the problem context.

In this meetup learn more about design thinking, and how it is being used to improve dashDB.

AGENDA:


WELCOME (6:00 - 6:25pm)

LET'S THINK TOGETHER (6:25pm - 6:45pm)

INTRO TO DESIGN THINKING (6:45pm- 7:15pm)

- Use case scenario example : IBM dashDB

- Description of the Design Thinking steps

HANDS-ON WORK IN GROUPS (7:15pm - 8:30pm)

Discussion: who do you think would benefit from using dashDB? · Brainstorm: what does this user want to achieve with this app? how can we make their experience great?

A step by step walk through to create personas, use cases and empathy maps to help empathize with users and design apps to better suit their needs


PRESENTER'S BIOS:

Maria Attarian

Maria is a software engineer working for IBM Canada Ltd. She is currently working on IBM dashDB, a role that required direct learning and application of all the principles of Design Thinking upon a real software product, within a fast pace environment based on continuous delivery and Agile development

Helen Kontozopoulos


Helen is a design thinking strategist who advises early stage startups on crafting software and hardware companies with design thinking, anthropology, marketing and lean startup business development tools. As a Co-Founder and General Partner of SMART LAUNCH she is integral in creating Canada's top seed funding and startup program for early-stage Internet of Things (IoT) & Artificial Intelligence (AI) companies which come out of Canadian universities.
She is the Director and Co-Founder of the technology conference, SMARTWEEK 2014/2015, an Internet of Things and Artificial Intelligence conference based in Toronto with Global partnered events.
Helen is a Lecturer at the University of Toronto, in the Department of Computer Science, where she teaches lean startup methodologies, design thinking and business innovation. She is on the UofT/IBM Watson teaching team.

Anna Kop


Anna is a user experience designer, applying principles of design thinking daily to improve healthcare apps. Feel free to reach out at @annakopster

name: Managing & Processing Big Data for Cancer Genomics, an insight of Bioinformatics
description:
Target audience and skill level:
Beginner to intermediate Computer Science / ICT
Absolute beginner in Biology / Cancer


Abstract:
We've heard it in the news: Today's advances in genomics can revolutionize the health care industry; however, what is not that often known, are the details about how the data is captured and manipulated, the size and types of these big data, and the need for privacy. In this presentation our guest speaker, Michael Moorhouse will give us an insight into the world of bioinformatics, and the current efforts underway to use it to predict, treat and cure diseases focusing on cancer.

Agenda:


6:00pm - 6:15pm
Introduction to Biology, DNA Sequencing machines, Cancer and 'personalised medicine'.

6:15pm - 6:20pm
About OICR (Ontario Insitute for Cancer Research): Mission, history and future


6:20pm - 7:00pm
Describing the general computational infrastructure used: locally and abroad.

7:00pm - 7:15pm: Break

7:15pm - 8:00pm
Demonstrations and Q&A

Biography of the speaker (in his own words):

Michael Moorhouse
I’m a Bioinformatician – a mixture of Biology, computer science and mathematics. My undergraduate degree is in ‘Biochemistry’ and having started programming computers aged eight I did my Masters degree in Bioinformatics because the overlap of the fields interested me. I’ve worked in the Netherlands, my home country of the UK and in Canada on a range of topics in the field of Bioscience and medical research for the past few years. Most of these involved ‘data munging’ to interface pre-existing tools and packages to my own software or filtering strategies. Quite quickly I became interested in Data Management: better management = less munging & better results with less pain. I have spent a lot of my time more recently assisting with the storage, transfer and security of the newer ‘Genomics’ data – specifically resulting from High Throughput DNA Sequencing - between international databases or consortia. My current roll is that of ‘Automation Engineer’ – aka. ‘Data Manager’ – at the OICR. Here I and the team are responsible safe and secure keeping of ~2 PB of data with a typical data set being in the ~20-50TB range

name: Semi-automated human genome annotation

venue.name: Princess Margaret Cancer Centre, Toronto Medical Discovery Tower, 4th floor, room 4-204

description:
This meetup has been set up in support of our friends at IEEE Toronto. Two topics will be covered:

Topic 1:
Semi-automated human genome annotation

Abstract:
Sequence census methods like ChIP-seq now produce an unprecedented amount of genome-anchored data. We have developed an integrative method to identify patterns from multiple experiments simultaneously while taking full advantage of high-resolution data, discovering joint patterns across different assay types. We apply this method to ENCODE chromatin data for multiple human cell types, including ChIP-seq data on covalent histone modifications and transcription factor binding, and DNase-seq and FAIRE-seq readouts of open chromatin. In an unsupervised fashion, we identify patterns associated with transcription start sites, gene ends, enhancers, CTCF elements, and repressed regions. The method yields a model which elucidates the relationship between assay observations and functional elements in the genome. This model identifies sequences likely to affect transcription, and we verify these predictions in laboratory experiments. We have made software and an integrative genome browser track freely available (http://pmgenomics.ca/hoffmanlab/proj/segway/).

Speaker:
Michael M. Hoffman (Assistant Professor in the Departments of Medical Biophysics and Computer Science, University of Toronto)

Topic #2:
Deep Autoencoder Neural Networks for Gene Ontology Annotation Predictions

Abstract:
The annotation of genomic information is a major challenge in biology and bioinformatics. Existing databases of known gene functions are incomplete and prone to errors, and the biomolecular experiments needed to improve these databases are slow and costly. While computational methods are not a substitute for experimental verification, they can help in two ways: algorithms can aid in the curation of gene annotations by automatically suggesting inaccuracies, and they can predict previously-unidentified gene functions, accelerating the rate of gene function discovery. In this work, we develop an algorithm that achieves both goals using deep autoencoder neural networks. With experiments on gene annotation data from the Gene Ontology project, we show that deep autoencoder networks achieve better performance than other standard machine learning methods, including the popular truncated singular value decomposition.

Speaker:
Davide Chicco (postdoctoral fellow at the Princess Margaret Cancer Centre, University of Toronto)

name: Big Data and Apache Hadoop - Just the Basics
description:
This is a new thing we're gonna try. 

Each time we do this meetup, we'll start with this Big Data and Hadoop Introductory session because we're getting new people all the time and we want a "standard way" to get them up to speed. 

This will be a 1 hour session and content will be the same every time. 

Immediately following these intro sessions, we'll dive deeper into a topic related to Big Data and Hadoop.

If you're just getting started with Big Data, this session is for you.

name: IBM | Spark - The start of something big in data & design (Web Conference Only))
description:
THIS IS A WEB CONFERENCE ONLY.  TIME OF WEB CONFERENCE LOCALLY IS BASED ON LIVE-STREAM START - PACIFIC DAYLIGHT TIME. DETAILS TO CONNECT TO LIVE-STREAM ARE INDICATED BELOW. 

Apache Spark is an open source processing engine built around speed, ease of use, and analytics. If you have large amounts of data that requires low latency processing that a typical Map Reduce program cannot provide, Spark is the alternative.

Spark performs at speeds up to 100 times faster than Map Reduce for iterative algorithms or interactive data mining. Spark provides in-memory cluster computing for lightning fast speed and supports Java, Scala, and Python APIs for ease of development. Spark allows data scientists to build models quickly and supports iterative jobs on distributed datasets. This means more people can apply deep intelligence into applications to make everything smarter, including the Internet of Things (IoT), machine learning, web, mobile, social, business process and more. 

Do you believe in the value of Spark, in the speed, efficiency and flexibility of this in-memory compute engine? IBM does.  Emphatically.That's why we're committed to do everything we can to accelerate the adoption of Spark for enterprise analytics, where Spark promises seemingly unlimited value.

On June 15, 2015, IBM will host a Spark Community event in San Francisco, California: IBM | Spark - The Start of Something Big in Data and Design. There will be a live demo showcase, refreshments, and a Town Hall discussion featuring some of the most trail-blazing data scientists in today's Spark Community, including:

•  Edd Dumbill, VP Strategy, Silicon Valley Data Science
•  Mike Tamir, Chief Science Officer & VP of Data Science & Education at Galvanize
•   Fernando Perez, Staff Scientist at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory & Founding Investigator of the Berkeley Institute for Data Science
•   Haoyuan Li, CEO and Founder of Tachyon Nexus
•   Shankar Venkataraman, Distinguished Engineer & CTO, IBM Analytics Platform at IBM
•   Paco Nathan, Director, Community Evangelism, Databricks

Spark Community members will also deliver 5-minute lightning talks to describe exciting projects they're working on.

We will provide a livestream presentation of what these Spark leaders have to say.

Live Streaming Link:

To get additional details about Spark you can sign up now for a reminder at:

http://www.ibm.com/analytics/us/en/technology/spark/

Scroll down to "Can't attend in Person"?  Sign up for a reminder and add it to your calendar.

Additional information on Spark:

Link to Spark Fundamentals Course in Big Data University

http://bigdatauniversity.com/bdu-wp/bdu-course/spark-fundamentals/

Link to Spark Technology Information

http://www.ibm.com/analytics/us/en/technology/spark/

Happy Sparking.

name: Data Science Panel and Introduction to Watson Analytics
description:
*** This meetup is co-hosted with the Toronto - Social, Mobile, Analytics and Cloud meetup ***

In this meetup we will feature two main presentations: (1) Watson Analytics and (2) Data Science Panel Discussion. 

This is also the inaugural event of the Data Science Series, a series of hands-on meetups where you get to learn and develop your data science skills. The DS Series will be held every Tuesday for beginner topics, and every Thursday for advanced topics, with free food, drinks, and wi-fi! 

Agenda

5:45pm - 6:00pm - Registration & Food 

6:00pm - 6:15pm - Event Introduction 

6:15pm - 7:15pm - Watson Analytics 

Watson Analytics offers cognitive, predictive, & visual analytics in an easy-to-use service you can use on your own to find answers in your data.

Speaker: Marc Altshullter (VP of Watson Analytics at IBM) 

7:15pm - 7:30pm - Data Scientist Workbench 

Polong Lin will introduce Data Scientist Workbench as a tool for analyzing data in Python, R, Scala in Jupyter-like notebooks with Apache Spark pre-installed. 

7:30pm - 8:15pm Data Science Panel Discussion

(Target Audience: Beginner to Intermediate Data Scientists)

What are local data scientists in Toronto working on? Want to learn how to find a job in data science? What programming languages do data scientists use? Find out in this panel session, where we bring in four data scientists and invite the audience to ask questions. 

Panelists:

- Murtaza Haider (Professor at Ryerson University) 

- Ashwin Tumne (Chief Data Scientist, Paytm Labs)

- Polong Lin (Data Scientist, Big Data University & IBM)

- Xiao-Ping (Steven) Zhang (Co-Founder & CEO, EidoSearch) 

--------------------------------------------------

+ Free food 
+ Free refreshments + Free wi-fi

name: Beginners: Analytics for All with Watson Analytics
description:
Registration: 

RSVPing to this meetup is not enough to attend. Please register   ===>>>here<<<===

Abstract: 

Join us in this hands-on Workshop with Watson Analytics experts. Go through an end-to-end scenario where you start from basic raw data, and end up with visualizations and insight!...more.

name: Faster time to value with Hadoop on the Cloud
description:
Join us to learn and experience how you could accelerate time to value out of the data that is stored in your Hadoop environment, by using out of the box analytics tools in the Cloud.

We will start with a short presentation on Hadoop overview followed by a hands-on lab to demonstrate the analytics tool on Hadoop on the cloud provided by IBM.

Pre-requisites:
- Bring your own laptop
- Please follow and complete the prep-work in advance for the hands-on lab.
  The prep-work instructions are in a word document (Toronto_Meetup_Prework_Hadoop_on_Cloud_HandsOnLab.doc) under Files Tab above.

Free Pizza and Drinks! Come learn, eat, and socialize!

This meet up is subjected to change.

name: Apply your big data and analytics skills with real sports data
description:

• CFL data

• TiCats data (CFL team)

• Traffic data

• Weather data

• Twitter data

We will also go over different tools you can use.

name: SportsHack 2015
description:
Two days. 

Three cities. 

Join more than 400 participants from across Canada for a weekend of creativity...this is your chance to utilize all of the tools and techniques you have received through attending previous meetups.

SportsHack will bring together teams of hackers in Toronto, Vancouver and Halifax to compete in developing innovative sports-related software solutions.

This year, in partnership with the Canadian Football League (CFL), SportsHack challenges you to develop real world technologies from the CFL's real world data.

Great prizes! Great Locations!  Amazing Data!

Register today!!

name: Introduction to R Programming
description:
http://bit.ly/2016bdur

1. Download the R notebook to your computer:

http://bit.ly/2016bdur

2. Log into Data Scientist Workbench.

3. Click on Build Analytics > Python/Jupyter Notebook, which opens the Notebook interface.

4. Drag-and-drop the notebook from your computer into the browser, and it will automatically upload to DSWB.

With over 2 million users worldwide, R is rapidly becoming the leading programming language in statistics and data science. Every year, the number of R users grows by 40%, and an increasing number of organizations are using it in their day-to-day activities. 


Click >>here<< to register and for more details!

You need to register for Data Scientist Workbench (datascientistworkbench.com) before this meet up. We will use R Notebooks and RStudio IDE embedded in Data Scientist Workbench to write and run the codes.

Click >> here << to register and for more details!

Audience: Beginners in Data Science

Presenter:  Polong Lin

name: Data Science Methodology+Classif­ication
description:
RSVPing to this meetup is not enough to attend. Please register   ===>>>here<<<===

What does a data scientist do when given a business problem? 

What are the steps in converting a business problem into a ​*data problem*​, and then solving it?

Come and learn about data science methodology - the mental flowchart of data scientists - from start to end.  We will start from a high, theoretical level, then jump into interactive sessions where we play the role of a data scientist. Use-case: Food!

“ Can we predict the cuisine of any recipe based on its ingredients?"
"If a food dish contains chicken and cumin, what cuisine is it most likely to be?”http://bigdatauniversity.com/courses/data-science-methodology/Hands-on - please ask attendees to bring laptop + register for DSWB and make sure they try logging in before the meetup.

Audience: Beginners in Data Science

Presenter:  Polong Lin

name: Introduction to Big Data and Hadoop
description:
RSVPing to this meetup is not enough to attend. Please register   ===>>>here<<<===

What is Big Data? How do we tackle Big Data? Why are we interested in it? What is a Big Data platform?

This meetup will emphasize that we study Big Data to gain insight that will be used to get  people throughout the enterprise to run the business better and to provide better service to customers. Rather than a implementation of a single open-source systems such as Hadoop, the course recommends that Big Data should be processed in a platform that can handle the variety, velocity, and volume of data by using a family of components that require integration and data governance.  Big Data is NoHadoop (“not only Hadoop”) as well as NoSQL (“not only SQL”)...more

Audience: Beginners in Big Data and Hadoop 

Presenter: Paul Yip

name: Apache Spark Maker Community Event
description:
On June 6, 2016, leading minds in data and analytics from Tesla, Netflix, Silicon Valley Data Science, and IBM will come together to demonstrate how open data and analytics technologies such as R, Spark, Python and more are forming a vibrant ecosystem.  The community has a shared goal of working with all data to build unexpected insights and launch new business applications.

The Apache Spark Maker Community Event will bring together data scientists, data engineers, data developers, and data designers June 6th @ 6pm at Galvanize, San Francisco. Here’s the plan:   

- The Big Reveal – New sample Apache Spark apps and tools

- Use Cases – Monsanto will share how they are using R and Spark to optimize their supply chain

- Learning Session - Hear from experts working on Spark projects and building the Spark ecosystem of open data and analytics technologies

- Networking Opportunity – Food, drinks and data, explore a Hall of Innovation showcasing Spark demos

Join us. Learn more here:  Apache Spark Maker Community Event 

Registration begins at 5:30 PM and the discussion starts at 6:30 PM; food and drinks will be served. You must register for this event. 

To get your ticket, and attend in person, click HERE. 

Can't attend in person? We'll be live streaming this event on a computer screen near you! Register for the  live stream and we'll send you a calendar update and login link.

name: Cluster Analysis
description:
Registration: 

RSVPing to this meetup is not enough to attend. Please register   ===>>>here<<<===

Cluster analysis (examples, and applications)

Clustering is the most important unsupervised learning problem in machine learning. 

Join us in this meetup to learn about cluster analysis, and its applications. You will learn to partition a set of data points into groups or clusters where the data in each cluster is as similar as possible. 

It is a hand-on session and you will practice clustering weather stations with python in DataScientistWorkbench.com .   Please register before attending the workshop.

Agenda: 

1) Introduction to cluster Analysis

2) K-means clustering

3) Hierarchical clustering

4) Big Data Clustering

Presenter: Saeed Aghabozorgi


</a>

<a href="https://ca.linkedin.com/in/paul-yip-15884918">

name: DeveloperConnect
description:
Join IBM for our new DeveloperConnect workshop on June 15th in Toronto!

A full day of real interactive discussions and hands-on labs with IBM developers and architects, who will get down to the technical aspects of the reality of app development now driven and deployed across multiple environments, implemented in a hybrid cloud. We’ll cover everything to help you Start, Code and Push your company to succeed in this brave new application world.

Complimentary breakfast and lunch will be provided. Bring your laptops to take advantage of the open hands-on labs and instructor-led cognitive app session!

In order to confirm your seat at this event, please be sure to register here:

http://ibm.co/1XN7cxH

The workshop will cover:

Start:
-- The App Evolution continues—the art of the possible
-- Achieve success in the API economy
-- Discover what's on the horizon...Blockchain, Swift and more

Code:
-- Dive in with hands-on labs - Watson, Mobile, IoT & more
-- Build your own cognitive app
-- Design an app with microservices

Push:
-- Create a roadmap to optimize the App Evolution
-- Deploy DevOps in a hybrid world

Pre-reqs for hands on labs will be available the week prior to the event.

name: Show Us Your Apps - Apache Spark Maker Build Global Hackathon
description:
THIS IS A GLOBAL ON-LINE HACKATHON THAT BEGINS MAY 23, 2016 AND NOW ENDS AUGUST 23, 2016.  SUBMISSIONS DUE AUGUST 23rd BY 5:00 PM EST. 

We’re extending the hackathon deadline to August 23 - that’s 20 additional days to build your Spark enterprise app. (View the revised competition calendar HERE.  We're giving you more time because....

We’re adding new enterprise data resources to the site and we want to give you a chance to incorporate these into your projects, if you so choose.  Our awesome data co-sponsors Yelp and Uncharted Software have generously shared some of their enterprise data sets for you to use during the hackathon.

Yelp’s data includes 2.2M reviews by 552K users for 77K businesses. The Uncharted data includes Bitcoin network transactions from processing the Bitcoin blockchain as of mid-2014 and Amazon product reviews from 1995 through 2003. For a fuller description and data access, visit our resources page.

Uncharted Software also has a couple cool Spark data visualization libraries you should check out: Salt and SparkPipe.

And, in case you’d like to weigh the effects of weather on business operations, we’re also offering access to the full suite of Weather Company APIs for the duration of the hackathon.

Finally, if you’re looking for a hosting solution for your Spark app, we’re now offering extended Bluemix trials for all hackathon participants. Using Bluemix services to build your project is totally optional, but might be a good way to get your app up and running — particularly with the IBM Analytics for Apache Spark service.

You can request your extended Bluemix trial code here. 

For all hackathon participants, trials will extend through November 1, 2016.

Now go forth and optimize for the enterprise!

---------------------

Build an Apache Spark application to address a real business problem or core concern related to customer care, marketing, risk management or operations. Join IBM and Devpost for a global hackathon using Apache Spark Makers Build.  There are $100,000 in cash prizes.  Submissions can be sent in up to August 23rd.

Participation Details: To participate in the global virtual hackathon, you can register here.  Please review all registration guidelines.

For the hack, you will apply Apache Spark's powerful analytics capabilities to enterprise and other relevant data so data scientists and software developers can build an analytics or mobile/web app that tackles a key business problem in marketing, customer case, operations or risk management.  The grand prize is $50,000, and the top three winners each get a meeting with the judge or
Spark community expert of their choice; the judging panel includes data experts from Tesla, Netflix, and Silicon Valley Data Science.

Go to apachespark.devpost.com for full details and registration.  Please review all registration rules.

Questions?

We're here to help. If you have any questions about the hackathon, post on the discussion forum or email support@devpost.com and we'll respond as soon as we can.

name: IBM Cloud Innovation Tour

venue.name: St. Andrew's Club and Conference Centre 150 King St. W Toronto, Ontario M5H 1J9 Canada St. Andrew's Website

description:
You need to innovate faster than ever before. But how do you truly reap the benefits of Cloud, while also optimizing and connecting to your existing IT? Come learn how to solve these challenges at Cloud Innovation Tour 2016. 

Start the day by getting inspired by guest keynote Robert Tercek, TEDx speaker, named as one of the “Digital Dozen” most influential players in new media. Then, with separate tracks designed to address your role in the organization, get up to speed on the latest cloud technologies that fuel innovation - including security, cognitive, APIs, mobility, integration, SaaS/PaaS, DevOps, object storage and more. Share challenges and ideas in roundtable discussions led by IBM CTOs, cloud architects and distinguished engineers. For developers, get your hands dirty with several hands-on labs in which you'll build cognitive and mobile apps using APIs, containers and SWIFT.


REGISTER HERE TO CONFIRM YOUR SEAT -  CLOUD INNOVATION TOUR


You’ll leave this event inspired by the art of the possible and, best of all, a clear roadmap to accelerate innovation with Cloud.

Who Should Attend:
- Discover track: IT Executives and Innovation Leaders
- Design track: IT Operations Managers and IT Architects
- Develop track: Development Managers and Developers

Reasons to Attend:
- Learn. Quickly get up to speed on the latest technologies that accelerate Cloud innovation.
- Accelerate. Hear client stories to understand how others have transformed using Cloud, and start to define your next steps.
- Network. Meet and network with local peers, influencers, business partners and IBM subject matter experts via roundtable discussions.


Register early - space is limited -- CLOUD INNOVATION TOUR

name: DataFirst Launch Event – Experience new ways to put your data to work
description:
On September 27, 2016, leading minds in data and analytics will come together and unveil the latest in cloud technology, enabling you to more efficiently put data to work. Experience how Spark, Hadoop, Python, and more are being used to bring together all types of data professionals –from data engineers, to data scientists, developers and business analysts –to work in new collaborative ways.

The IBM DataFirst Launch Event will unite data and analytics leaders and practitioners from the open source community, startups, and enterprises. Check the event site for the latest lineup of guest speakers. The event takes place @ 6pm at the Hudson Mercantile Building, NYC.

Here’s the plan:
• The Big Reveal –Experience new ways to work for data engineers, data scientist, developers, and business analysts, both individually and collectively.

•Hands-on sessions – With interactive experiences for each of these professions.

•Use Cases –Community leaders and guest speakers will share their expertise and vision
•Networking Opportunity – Food, drinks, data, collaborative demos, and a party on the rooftop

Learn more here:  DataFirst Launch Event

Check-in and networking begins at 6:00 PM.  Food and drinks will be served. You must register for this event.

To get your ticket, and attend in person, click HERE.  

Can't attend in person? We'll be live streaming this event.  Register for the LIVE STREAM and we'll send you a calendar update and login link.

name: IBM Champions - Call for Nominations
description:
IBM values our community of clients and business partners. Each year, we support and build our community by working closely with IBM advocates and helping them to become 

IBM Champions

IBM Champions are a select group of external advocates made up of clients, business partners and independent consultants who make exceptional contributions to the technical community by speaking at conferences, running or actively participating in user groups, evangelizing relevant technical topics via social media, and helping our clients make the most of IBM technology. 

We are looking for clients and business partners to join the program and are looking for applications in the areas of data science, data engineering, application development, and business analytics.

Nominations are due by Monday, November 28, 2016

The Champion program is open to candidates worldwide, and candidates may self-nominate or be nominated by someone else. IBM employees are not eligible for the program.  Some benefits of the IBM Champion program: 
- IBM Champions advocate IBM offerings in the community with competence and credibility (content, blogs, presentations, customer references, analyst/press, videos/podcasts, etc.)
- IBM Champions share knowledge with and provide support to the IBM user community (books, articles, blogs, forums, presentations, education, beta programs and customer advisory councils etc.)
- IBM Champions support IBM as brand ambassadors who build awareness, share product knowledge, and provide product feedback as users and beta testers

Read this  blog post  for full IBM Champion program criteria, guidelines and the <a>nomination form</a>.

To learn more about the IBM Champion program from current Champions and Worldwide IBM Champion coordinator Libby Ingrassia, listen to this webcast. Be sure to share the blog and webcast with clients and colleagues who would make great IBM Champions.

name: Making Data Simple in the Cognitive Era
description:
RSVP: http://bit.ly/2gOcufe

This webinar will cover an overview of Watson Data Platform capabilities and how to empower users across the organization to make the most out of their data. What if you can shorten the time it takes to create value out of your existing organizational data ? 

What if you can provision a common analytic engine with managed services that will enable you to embrace multiple cloud platforms ? IBM Watson Data Platform is the first cloud-based data and analytics platform to support cognitive businesses. It enables access, collaboration and paths to insights by connecting all users through trusted access to a variety of data, discovering new possibilities and opportunities with built-in intelligence, automation and machine learning and accelerating outcomes with rapid deployment of new data models and fast embedding of insights into processes, applications and services. 

Let us show you how Watson Data Platform can be the milestone of your organization analytics strategy and empower your organization into the new Cognitive analytics era.

Speaker Bio:
Gerardo Rodríguez Díaz – is an avid traveler, technologist enthusiast and Big data and Analytics cloud solution specialist focused on communications and computer systems integrations industries across North America. GRD areas of specialization are IT, Marketing and Business Intelligence having worked across European, North and South American markets.

name: Machine Learning Launch
description:
The demand for machine learning is booming! 

Calling all IT executives, data scientists, Chief Data Officers, data architects and other data geeks.  Join us on February 15th from 2:00-5:30 pm ET via livestream  (replay available starting February 16th) , and discover how machine learning is fundamentally changing the way we work and live.  Hear about cognitive applications that anticipate behavior and learn from data without being explicitly programmed.

You'll learn about the latest breakthrough developments on machine learning as well as Spark, data and analytics. Mike Gualtieri, Vice President and Principal Analyst, Forrester, will present his view on how to best leverage technologies such as big data, predictive analytics, Hadoop/Spark, machine learning, data science, and AI.  Rob Thomas, General Manager, IBM Analytics will host an agenda which will include guest speakers and cover the following topics:

•  Machine Learning Overview

•  Top Trends in Machine Learning & Cognitive Applications

•  Cognitive Analytics and Machine Learning for the Enterprise

•  Live Product Demonstration & Client Roundtable on Machine Learning

•  Data Innovation with Hybrid Transaction/Analytical Processing

•  Spark & Machine Learning for Enterprise Systems

For additional details and to REGISTER, please visit MACHINE LEARNING.

Register NOW and we'll send you a reminder!
how_to_find_us: Livestream is Eastern Standard Time (EST) - Adjust to your time zone

name: Innovations in Big Data

venue.name: The Sandbox by the DMZ (Ryerson Campus, 3rd Floor)

description:
Speakers

James Tieu, Open Source Analytics Evangelist, IBM
Marc Martina, Systems Architect, TechD.

Description


Big data and distributed computing allows for better and faster insights. This meetup will share:

• Trends in analytics, cloud, data lake/warehouse, hybrid cloud

• New affordable approaches to leverage Netezza, Streams

• IBM’s innovations in open source, Hadoop, Spark

Itinerary

6:00 – 6:30: Big Data Overview, Marc Martina

6:30 - 7:00: DashDB / Pure Data for Analytics (Netezza) – Marc Martina

7:00 – 7:10: Break

8:10 – 9:00: Networking/refreshments
